content.webTitle: BBC releases Sherlock preview for fans celebrating hearth and Holmes

fields.headline: BBC releases Sherlock preview for fans celebrating hearth and Holmes
fields.bodyText: We knew he survived, but we just didn't know how. At the end of the second season of the BBC's acclaimed modern reimagining of Sherlock Holmes, our hero leapt from the top of a London high-rise, only to re-emerge in the shadows at his own burial. In a seven-minute teaser episode released on Christmas Eve, no further clues were offered to explain Sherlock's improbable feat. Still, the BBC knows exactly what its viewers want for Christmas: something to tide us over until the third season starts in the new year. “Sherlock has been gone for two years. But someone isn't quite convinced that he's dead … #SherlockLives,” the BBC teased from its YouTube account. The short video, entitled Many Happy Returns, sets the stage for Sherlock (played by Benedict Cumberbatch) to return to London. His friends still think he's dead; his sidekick Watson (Martin Freeman) even wound up in therapy. As Many Happy Returns begins, we find that a series of crimes across the globe, from New Dehli to Germany, have been solved by almost impossible means. The pattern hasn’t gone unnoticed. Back in London, Detective Anderson – never a big fan of Sherlock’s – has been tracking the cases. "He’s out there. He’s hiding, but he can’t stop himself from getting involved,” he insists to Inspector Lestrade over a pint. Lestrade isn’t convinced. But that doesn’t stop him from visiting Watson, who’s spending his days alone with a glass of fine spirit, and giving him an uncut version of a video greeting Sherlock recorded for Watson. Watson pops in the disc, and we see Sherlock pacing and whining as he considers the what to say. But only at the end, is the real message clear. “I’ll be seeing you again very soon,” Sherlock drawls. At that precise moment, the doorbell rings. Watson hits pause and gets up to answer the door. Moments later, the video begins to play again, and we see Sherlock offering the camera a wink and a sly, knowing grin. Will Sherlock reveal himself right away, or will he let his colleagues solve the mystery themselves for once? Who hit the play button? Was it Sherlock popping by to say hello, or is a new, unseen enemy at the door? Does that moment even matter at all, or are we reading too much into this? We could probably come up with better theories, but we’re all a bit busy freaking out. Fret not – we’ll soon have the answers: Sherlock premieres in the UK on 1 January, 2014. US fans will have to wait until 19 January, 2014, when it will air on PBS.
